trial_identification.studytitle: In extremely low birth weight (ELBW) infants who require positive pressure at birth does the Neopuff Infant Resuscitator compared with the Laerdal Infant Bag improve oxygen saturation measurements in the first ten minutes of life?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In extremely low birth weight (ELBW) infants who require positive pressure at birth does the Neopuff Infant Resuscitator compared with the Laerdal Infant Bag improve oxygen saturation measurements in the first ten minutes of life?

conditions.healthcondition: Oxygen saturation in the first ten minutes of life in infants born at less than 29 weeks gestation who require positive pressure ventilation

interventions.interventions: A randomised controlled trial of the Laerdal infant resuscitator (control) to provide positive pressure ventilation (in line with the Australian Resuscitation Council guidelines) during resuscitation of infants born at less than 29 weeks gestation. The duration of the trial is 18 months, we anticipate completing recruitment in August 2008.
interventions.comparator: A randomised controlled trial of the Neopuff (comparator) to provide positive pressure ventilation (in line with the Australian Resuscitation Council guidelines) during resuscitation of infants born at less than 29 weeks gestation.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The difference in oxygenation saturation from the first measurement soon after birth until 10 minutes of age.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured soon after birth until 10 minutes of age

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 1. Time for heart rate to rise above 100 bpm
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured soon after birth until 10 minutes of age.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 2. Incidence of intubation and ventilation in the first 24 hours of life.
3. Tidal volumes delivered during the first 10 minutes of life
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured soon after birth until 10 minutes of age.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 4. To determine whether the response to each device varies with: a. gestational age b. type of birth (vaginal or caesarean) c. absence/presence of labour d. antenatal steroids
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured soon after birth until 10 minutes of age.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: All infants born <29 weeks gestation in need of positive pressure ventilation, because of inadequate respiration and/or a heart rate of less than one hundred beats per minute (HR <100 bpm) will be eligible for resuscitation and therefore entry to this study.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Infants will be excluded from final analysis if they have a condition that might have an adverse effect on breathing or ventilation apart from prematurity or asphyxia.

trial_design.concealment: Sequentially numbered, sealed, opaque envelopes containing the allocation will be opened by the senior doctor pjust before birth. Allocation will be stratified by gestational age (23-26 and 27-28 weeks)

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Neonatal Services The Royal Women's Hospital Cnr Grattan St and Flemington Road Parkville Victoria 3052

fundingsource.fundingname: National Health and Medical Research Council Program Grant

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
While positive end expiratory pressure (PEEP) is always used during intermittent positive pressure ventilation (IPPV), there are no current recommendations about the use of PEEP or continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) during neonatal resusciation.
The Neopuff is a manual ventilation device which delivers PEEP or CPAP. The Laerdal bag is the commonest manual ventilation device in use worldwide and does not deliver PEEP.
Our hypothesis is that the delivery of PEEP or CPAP to very premature infants at birth may lead to a more rapid improvement in lung volume and therefore oxygenation.
